Message.Title: What percentage of revenue and or profits is the dreamliner? I am concerned about the second plane having a crack detected and wonder if the whole dreamliner fleet may be grounded until a fix is completed. Thanks

Topic.Title: What percentage of revenue and or profits is the dreamliner? I am concerned about the second plane having a crack detected and wonder if the whole dreamliner fleet may be grounded until a fix is completed. Thanks

Message.Msg: The crack is in the GE engine, NOT the airplane; GE will warranty these engines and fix the problem, so there will be no impact on Boeing. FAA has already addressed this issue with requirement for ultrasonic inspections every 90 days (which GE will no doubt pay for). GE already has a new coating process in place and will replace the affected engines as parts become available. So this will be a non issue.

Message.Title: Thank You President Obama
Message.Msg: the gov't can't spend itself out of a recession, what fools NEW YORK -- FedEx Corp. says the global economy is stalling, and it's going to get worse next year. The conditions are shrinking earnings at the world's second-largest package delivery company. Factories are making fewer items for FedEx to ship and customers are opting for cheaper delivery options to save money. FedEx on Tuesday cut its outlook for global growth and industrial production while slashing the forecast for company earnings. And CEO Fred Smith suggested trade has slowed to levels seen during the last two significant economic downturns.

Message.Title: The flood gates of a work stop will lower Boeing stock price and hurt business thanks Chicago MGT
Message.Msg: Local officials say they are puzzled at how the situation has unfolded. Some compare the current tension to 2008, when they say Boeing's Chicago leaders thought the offer to the machinists union would be accepted by members. The members soundly rejected it, and later voted to go on a costly, bitter, 57-day strike. "I think Chicago is making the same mistake with Speea," said Hamilton, at Leeham, referring to the company's Midwestern headquarters. He thinks members will strongly reject the contract.

Topic.Title: Socialism vs. capitalism

Message.Msg: To convert the business man into the profiteer is to strike a blow at capitalism … The business man is only tolerable so long as his gains can be held to bear some relation to what, roughly and in some sense, his activities have contributed to society." One reason for the problems we face today is that we have stopped seeing taxes as an essential institution in this capitalist economy for if taxes could be raised on those who can most afford to pay them, public services would not have to be cut. We should see taxes as an integral part of a moral capitalist economy, providing health, education and social care outside the market. People should not be afraid to join Warren Buffett in saying the rich should pay their fair share of taxes.

Message.Title: Pentagon seeks competition for F-35 program
Message.Msg: Fri Sep 28, 2012 8:35pm EDT * Pentagon plans to meet with companies Nov. 14-15 * Seeks possible competitors for simulators, support equipment * No deal yet on next batch of production planes By Andrea Shalal-Esa WASHINGTON, Sept 28 (Reuters) - The Pentagon on Friday moved toward bringing in other companies to operate and maintain its most expensive weapons program, the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, a step that could reduce revenues for the current prime contractor, Lockheed Martin Corp. The move is the latest action by the Pentagon to drive down the cost of the new single-engine, single-seat warplane, whose operations and maintenance costs are currently projected to reach a staggering $1.11 trillion over the coming decades. Last week, top Pentagon and Air Force officials publicly slammed Lockheed's performance on the new radar-evading jet, whose development and production alone are slated to cost $396 billion. The officials said they were looking at ways to introduce more competition to the program.
